full_text:
In the Land of Dixie Peach
Grease, oil, shine, and slick...words that have a pecular fascination and
preoccupation among Black Americans. Grease, oil, rub, shine. The bane of
all darker Americans was to appear "ashy" - that is, to have visible evidence
of the scaly dryness that accompanies any situation where the skin is exposed to
the elements for any length of time. Since this condition was more visibly
evident on their bodies, Black Americans sought to avoid being seen in this
state in public. Daily, as thousands of school children left their homes,
they were inspected by their mothers to make sure they were neat, and
greased. Grease was also an important component of the hair straightening
process. It served as a protective shield for the hair shaft against the
ravages of the hot comb, and served also as the catalyst that resulted
in the end-product-straight, swinging, shining hair, a home-grown version of
the Breck Girl, Long and Silky, etc., etc. of white america. Crinkled hair
just didn't carry the shine like straightened hair!
But grease and oil, while they were important components in the Black American's
life, it was also his "badge of shame". The worse sin that this same school child
could commit was to get grease on his homework. It would then be out there. for
all to see a spot revealing the nitty-gritty of attempting to conform to the
shining, sparkling American Ideal. It also smacked of the worse kind of ethnicity -
it was about fried chicken, barbeque, fat back, etc., etc., and that was ever
sooo country.
4
DAVID HAMMONS, in his latest exhibition, GREASY BAGS AND BARBEQUE BONES, at
JUST ABOVE MIDTOWN GALLERY takes this obsession with grease, and raises it to
a level of visual consciousness within the Black experience. Using barbeque bones
and bags with greasy stains, Hammons in the tradition of the dada found object",
and surrealist juxtaposition forces us to look at the refuse of our experience,
and see the pecular aesthetic potentialities: patterns that grease makes, the
special way that grease reacts with porous brown paper. He moves from the "found"
patterns to creating his own in a manner similar to the technique of staining
canvas with diluted pigments, thereby achieving blotted markings and free-form
shapes. The multiplicity of forms makes direct reference to mass production, the
super--super market, shopping bags...shopping bags which have doubled as suitcases,
garbage bags; bags into which Blacks have put cotton balls; cotton balls which
resemble balls of cut pre-straightened, pre-processed kinky hair, which is encased
in stocking caps to keep the "'cess" in place...Cotton Club! Sparkle! Glitter!
Ellington and Baker! Shine, shine on! The entire excercise is carried to another
pertinent sociological plane as the viewer is confronted with the bags, which
proudly proclaim on the bottom edge: "We are ecology minded. This bag will self-
destruct in Mother Earth". Then Hammons' work also becomes a statement, however
intentional or inadvertent, about recycling and ecology.
This exhibition continues Hammons' more familiar grease projects, the Body Print,
a process of oiling the body, and then printing it on paper with baby powder, and
powdered pigments, dealing again with the imprint of grease on paper, and its
relationship particularly with the Black body. In conjunction with his New York
exhibition, JUST ABOVE MIDTOWN GALLERY is sponsoring a "Body Print-In" on Monday,
May 19, 1975. The impulse, as explained by gallery director and owner, Linda Bryant,
is to involve the public in the creation of a work of art from their own physical
center.
A viewing of the reality.that Hammons presents to us is essential, even if only
to satisfy your curiosity. One thing is certain, you may hate it or like it,
but you will not forget it for a long time...
1
LSSims
